title: Portraits of Douglass and Tubman - purpose

content.description:

Source 2Bisa Butler, African American Artist, I Go to Prepare a Place for You, 2021 Quilted Portrait of Harriet Tubman, Based on an 1868 Photograph of Tubman
© Bisa Butler. Collection of the Smithsonian National Museum of African American History and Culture, purchased through the American Women’s History Initiative Acquisitions Pool, administered by the Smithsonian American Women’s History Initiative
content.question: Which of the following statements best describes the purpose of photographic portraits of African American leaders, like the one in Source 1?

choices.label: They were used by enslavers to help track and return African Americans who had escaped from slavery.
They aimed to refute stereotypes about Black people by showing them as dignified and respectable.
They were used by visual artists to demonstrate the technological superiority of photography over painting.
They were used by emigrationists to persuade African Americans that they can build better lives for themselves in Africa.

content.answer: They aimed to refute stereotypes about Black people by showing them as dignified and respectable.
